location.merchant_description_html: A better tea experience awaits! Fresh teas, friendly service, and phenomenal savings. See why people like you are making a switch to better tea...

The only place friendlier than a local corner store is one that’s sunny with all glass walls. Kind of like BMC. It’s the sort of place where you'd stock up on snacks for a spontaneous art-filled jaunt through the SoWa market just down the road. If you’re hungry for a real masterpiece, BMC’s got the Rowboat Sandwich: Boar’s Head pepper turkey with lettuce, pastrami, provolone, and honey mustard. I may be better off with a snack-soda duo. Good thing it’s ALSO a full convenience store.
A better tea experience awaits! Fresh teas, friendly service, and phenomenal savings. See why people like you are making a switch to better tea...
A better tea experience awaits! Fresh teas, friendly service, and phenomenal savings. See why people like you are making a switch to better tea...

Finizio’s is a delicious pizzeria which encourages B-ing YO. This is key because it’s located next to a liquor store. Need I say more? Alright, I will say more. But only in terms of the best possible pizza-alcohol pairings. Take the Four Cheese Pizza, a thin-crust pie smothered with an appetite-melting layer of mozzarella, provolone, romano and American cheese. Topped with fresh, sliced tomato...it  practically begs for a bottle of Pinot. If you feel like going the 6-pack route, grab an order of wings. Hops and hot sauce are a match made in Friday night heaven.

The winner for most versatile meal in Reading terminal Market is...*suspense*...*drum roll*....*on-stage streaker*....Profi’s Creperie! Let’s get down to the accolades! The $7.50 savory crepes provide the perfect foundation for serious sustenance like grilled chicken, roast beef or fresh seafood. All savory crepes are served with cheese and a colorful smattering of veggies. *applause* The $6.50 sweet crepes, which come dusted  in powdered sugar, can collaborate with fresh fruit, Nutella, and a variety of candy-sauces. Go a La Mode for $7.95 and you’re headed straight into epic dessert territory. *cheers*

Gluten free in Lakeview? The Cassava plant is your new best friend. It’s most commonly used in tropical entrees but here, it’s the main ingredient used to make mouth-watering gluten-free Baked Empanadas, Chili and Cassava rolls. Cassava rolls are flavorful, golf-ball sized bread bites that come in five flavors including white cheddar jalapeno, sun dried tomato and basil, even one with a melted chocolate center. The bread is baked in small batches every 30 minutes to ensure freshness! You can also purchase bulk frozen Empanadas and Cassava Rolls to bake for your guests. #GFreeParTay.

East Village Farm & Grocery is open 24-hours per day, making them the go-to for “how did I miss that?” dinner ingredients. Don’t worry, most people don’t know what shallots are either. The recently renovated space is bright, pristine and organized, so the search for the elusive sweet onions is a short one. Beware, perusing the stocked aisles on the way out can be awfully inspiring. A carton of eggs? Breakfast in bed! A bag of fresh-picked Granny Smith’s? A spontaneous apple crisp! And don’t forget a bouquet of fresh flowers. Read my lips: boyfriend of the year.

I snuck into bed in the dark. The light snapped on, and my wife stared from the other side of the bed. “Len, you were with Woody again, weren’t you?!” As I stammered, my onion-scented Cheesesteak breath leaked out. She gasped. “KNEW it! All this foodie foolin’ around ‘til 4AM on weekends... Shaved sirloin Cheesesteaks, all melty with cheese and onions on a fresh roll. Didja add mushrooms and peppers too, Len? Didja?!” I tried to calm her. “Bet you were all cozied up with an Italian Sausage, too. The LEAST you could’ve done was bring me a milkshake. Enjoy the couch tonight.” ...Totally worth it.

Listen here. Be careful when you hang at The Real Deal in JP, it’s dangerously delicious and Phantom-approved. Here’s how you play it: Cash in on a Sammy “The Bull” Gravano, packed with cracked pepper turkey, muenster cheese, bacon avocado and tomato. If you want to crank up the heat, wife up a Carmela Soprano: a roasted eggplant and provolone panini, smothered in pesto mayonaise. Think you can hang with the big boys? The biggest terror on the menu is King Kong, a ½ lb. burger topped with bleu cheese, onion rings and Frank’s Red Hot. Grab some backup napkins. It’s going to be a hand to bread battle and...there will be juice.

Attention power players on the Hill: the comfort, cafeteria-style food of Ashburton cafe is so good, you have to pass through security to gain admission. Kidding, the metal detector is mandatory for government-buildings like the McCormack...but the food IS suspiciously delicious and criminally priced. For less than $5, snag a made-to-order burger and fries or a fully-loaded pasta bowl, complete with grilled meat, fresh veggies and savory sauce. In addition to the permanent station menus, there are also daily specials. Republicans and Democrats alike have been known to cry out, “Poached lemon dill salmon day?!” and proceed to do a short, succinct jig.

A hungry Digitas designer is stopped in his tracks by the scent of seasoned tomato sauce. “We’ve got a Viga in this building?” A woman exiting, blissfully eating a fresh-baked roll chuckles. Inside, our Digi-hero is floored by the operation. Fresh Salads are furiously being mixed in one line. Specialty Sandwiches are wrapped and tossed “fish-market style” in another. Steaming heaps of Pasta are unloaded into cartons and sizzling Pizzas fly out of the oven every 5 mins. “This is insanely efficient,” he mutters. And, it’s open exclusively to Digitas employees. Your designer’s grind just got in-Viga-rated, DigiMan.

Condesa Coffee is a barista mecca of sorts. The best baristas work there, and green baristas want to learn from the masters. This is great news for the coffee-making-impaired. Where there are good baristas, there’s: Fierce flavor. Drip coffee. And...Latte design. Condesa doesn’t disappoint. Their Counter Culture Coffee is always brewed with an awesomely scientific attitude. They also seek to serve 12 complex, aromatic blends of Intelligentsia Tea. Caffeine conquered, sit back, relax and sip your beverage of choice while enjoying the modern, industrial decor that makes Condesa feel oh so swanky.

At JJ’s Gourmet Burgers in the TCC food court, your ordering experience begins with a form. It’s the best paperwork you’ll do all day. Select your patty, tick off some grill toppings and make note of how you’d it done. And for angus sake, amuse yourself, the staff and the rest of the lunch audience by attaching a fake name on your order. “Cheeseburger for Crazy Eyes FitzPatrick!”  When your freshly grilled burger arrives on a chewy baguette, hit the self serve toppings bar. Take as much as you want, of whatever you want. Translation: welcome to the onion carnival.

The Red Hat has been around for 100 years. Formerly the #1 hangout of seafarers, it side stepped prohibition by operating as a restaurant by day and a speakeasy by night. Coincidentally, their lethal, homemade buffalo sauce should be illegal. It engulfs the crisp breading on the best Wings in West End history. And don’t think for a second that they’ve taken their proximity to the harbor for granted. The strength of their fisherman connection is evident in the hearty, alfredo-laced Maine lobster ravioli. And prohibition? It’s over! Pull up a stool from 11AM-2AM for an ice cold Bud. Ah, freedom.

In Italy, a “razdora” is a homemaker who creates everything from scratch. At Casa Razdora, the scent of simmering sauces greets visitors at the door. The lunch rush is serious, but this FiDi gem churns out hunger-breakers at top speed. Turkey tips, bright dried cranberries and pecans mingle with the greenery in Serre Salads. Pastas like gnocchi and fusilli are enhanced by enticing sauces like Burro e Salvia (butter and sage) or smooth Pesto with basil and pine nuts. Lunch is made to your desire, just follow the house rules: Respect your elders whose pictures are all the wall, and futbol.

“I didn’t think they did that anymore?!” Our excited patron is referring to the lost art of tossing pizza dough. In a world of mass frozen crusts, it’s rare to make your own dough AND bake it in an authentic brick oven. The Works Pizza would disagree. Here’s a Supreme Pizza coming out of the oven. It’s covered from crust to crust in pepperoni, Italian sausage, peppers, onions and olives. It’s so packed, we can hardly see the cheese! We’ll revert to our patron for the verdict. What do you think? “Itz deleciuz.” Pepperoni gotcha tongue? We’ll translate: it’s phenomenal pie.

Somewhere between roasted garlic and cheese whiz are the myriad choices and combinations for Paolo’s pizza dough details. Like his U-Arts neighbors, Paolo’s not afraid to get experimental. He blends flavors on his culinary palette for our distinguishing palates. His Taco Pizza adds steak and lettuce to traditional pie, while the Chicken Parmigiana Pizza features delightful bits of breaded cutlets and basil. He’s free to be abstract because he’s mastered the principles of form: just try the Margherita.

Philly's historic 120-year-old Reading Terminal Market is an awe-inspiring spectacle of handmade goods, fresh produce and duck. Wait, duck you say? Sang Kee Peking Duck House, the same family-run, three-story Hong Kong icon on North 9th Street, offers fast, mouthwatering options like Peking Style Duck Rolls wrapped with duck, plum sauce and cabbage ready to be eaten on the go. Or, for those looking to sit and people watch, the Pork Dumpling Noodle Soup is a real firequacker! (Sorry, we had to do it.)

I’m on the other side of Reading Terminal when my By George! sensors go off. Somehow the steaming, sweet scent of a Steak and Caramelized Onion Stromboli has snaked across the market to my nostrils. Fresh out of the oven. I have exactly 32.7 seconds to get there before it’s gone. I jump up and begin counter-hopping. When the next leap felt too far, I found inspiration in BG’s menu: homemade sauce and pasta. Freshly-pressed paninis. Brick-oven pizza. Prize in-sight, I somersault to the floor and snag my ‘boli from an unsuspecting woman. Impressed with my skills, she yielded fully.

I know a place in Reading Terminal market where “fried” and “greasy” are profane terms, never uttered. It’s the same place that serves up Vegetarian Lasagna that I must cut down in private as to not insult my jaw. Quiet! Don’t let it hear you talk about its hinge handicap. Once it’s halfed, I’ll let it devour the luscious layers, letting fresh ricotta and spinach fly with wild abandon. Don’t take my word for it. Go to Mezze and taste the hummus and olives for yourself. The Mediterranean flavor is addictive, you’ll be hooked instantly. WARNING: Their seemingly endless glass case is no place for window shopping.

The Lower East Side has tons of great things to offer: awesome bars, gourmet restaurants, and beautiful people, to name a few. Local grocery stores, however, are few and far between. Corner Grocer on Orchard addresses that fundamental need, and does so with effortless style. With a full organic juice bar, multiple hot and cold sandwiches made fresh to order, and plenty of vegan and organic shopping items, Corner Grocer is anything but your standard market. This is truly grocery shopping with a LES twang!

Dilemma: You’re craving an authentic Mexican meal but don’t want it to sit in your stomach like a boulder. Answer? Quality ingredients at Maya Sol. With heaping portions of beans, freshly made hot sauce, cheese, pico de gallo, sour cream and guacamole, we recommend the burritos. They're packed to the gills like there’s a no carry-on policy. Or a pupusa! As fun to eat as it is to say, these round pockets of joy are made from corn tortillas so the outside’s delicate and crunchy and the inside’s warm and soft. ¡Buen apetito!

Maximo’s Deli has mastered the science of the sandwich. How do they construct a sandwich that is so delicious, so affordable and so addictive? Lets dissect their signature specimen: The Muffaletta Sandwich. Smooth provolone is carefully folded and stacked on Muffaletta bread, which is focaccia-like in it’s airy nature. Pending on the preference of the diner, it’s then is either composed of a ham, turkey or salami core. The intricacy of the lunch staple comes in the form of homemade dressing that sandwich is delicately doused on top in before being bread bookended. Creation decoded.

“Breakfast is the most important meal of the day.” That used to be your excuse for a fashionably late entrance to first period Calc. But if you’re bright enough to get into Columbia, you know it’s just the dang truth.  For meals in the morning, Camille’s in Morningside Heights is the quad-facing cafeteria alternative. At lunch and dinner, they’ve got a full service dining room with portions as big as text books, prices as reasonable as a mathematical proof, and as many menu items as electives. Whopping Tuna Melts, Personal Pizzas and lemon-butter sauteed Filet of Sole are the ultimate upgrade. I love college.

My relationship with Buffalo Wings is always testy, and Atomic Wings amplifies the tension. First, I choose a style (Buffalo, Boneless or ½ and ½.) Determining flavor is where legends are born. I can go with sweet sauces like BBQ, a “Sane” sauce (you know, where the Mild things are), or I can go big. The “Insane” sauces: Abusive, Nuclear, or Suicidal. I opt for a crispy, battered Suicide mission with a side of the Famous Waffle Fries and a Chicken Wrap. Today, Wings, you will bow to my digestive power.

Don’t tell my boss, but I’m most productive from 1PM-2PM, during my lunch break. I race over to Reading Terminal and place my 3-part order at my joint: Golden Bowl. I lay out my utensils with surgeon-like precision. Order Up! I dive into the Hot and Sour Soup, quenching my thirst for fierce flavor. While tilting my cup up to get the last drop, my hand is already at work twirling the soft noodles of my Vegetable Lo Mein. Multi-tasking at its best. As I crunch the last snap pea, I turn to the main event: Moo Shu Beef with Pancakes. I place a portion of steaming meat in the center of the warm pancake. Sauce it. Fold it. Eat. Repeat. Damn, I’m efficient.

I don’t like to get political, but it happens in FiDi. The strength of any platform has to start with a solid foundation. Call them a flip-flopper, but Pavia has 6 different bread bases to choose from. The Chicken Parmesan on a to-vote-for focaccia is the obvious front runner for a lunchtime decision. But a Chicken Fajita Pizza or one of 10+ weekday rotations of pasta, salad, pizza and calzone specials could end up being your midday underdog. So, I think I’ll just Occupy Pavia for the time being...

Equal Exchange Cafe is green. And not just because it’s located next to the TD Bank North Garden, home of the Celtics. Equal Exchange is the city’s leading importer and roaster of certified organic coffee. Every cup is made to order, with fair trade beans. Many say that their brews are so flavorful that they don’t require milk or sugar! In addition to caffeine, this cafe also boasts small plates ranging from sandwiches to sushi. When you’ve finished your last bite and sipped your last drop, be sure to toss them appropriately. Most of Equal Exchange’s products are packaged with compostable materials, reducing the cafe’s trash to just 1 lb. per day!

Imagine a spot at the foot of the Williamsburg Bridge that serves unrivaled Italian food in gigantic portions. Now envision a welcoming, jovial staff behind the counter; a rarity in an otherwise cold and gritty New York Pizza underworld. You take a bite of your Chicken Marsala Pizza. A wave of tangy, sweet and savory sauce rolls over your taste buds all at once. Behind the counter, a man in an apron smiles at you intently, probing for a nod of approval. This, my friend, is your happy place.
